results.title: The American soldier = Der Americkanische soldat
results.brief_description: In what Fassbinder describes as a ‘study of a perfect killer’ his American soldier is actually a German, recently returned from Vietnam with some newly developed skills to exploit. Stepping into the Munich underworld as a hired killer, Ricky (in his white suit and soft hat, one of the many movie references scattered throughout this noir-influenced thriller) finds he has entered a world of bluff and double-bluff, from the opening card game to the closing pay-off. Although the characters may be familiar from earlier Fassbinder films - the ageing rent-boy, the fickle moll, and unsmiling, sadistic policemen - the director has added a significance and weight to their cliched behaviour and stereotypical actions that invest the film with a knowing cynicism and a very dark humour. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: The American nightmare
results.creator_credit: Adam Simon, Jonathan Sehring, Colin MacCabe, Paula Jalfon and Independent Film Channel
results.brief_description: In this documentary, focusing on horror films from the 60s and 70s, director and screenwriter Adam Simon convincingly argues that the artists crucial to those works (in particular the directors) were reflecting the greater problems facing American society at that time - the Vietnam War, corruption of government, the conflicts of the Civil Rights movement and the divisiveness between generations. Interviews with key directors and scholars is interspersed with extensive clips from films such as “The Last house on the left” and “Night of the living dead” as well as news footage from Vietnam, political assassinations and other terrifying world events. Interviewees include: George A. Romero, John Carpenter, Tom Savini, David Cronenberg, Wes Craven, Tobe Hooper, John Landis. Contains graphic images and please note, some scenes may disturb.

results.title: The American Film Institute salute to Jimmy Stewart
results.creator_credit: Marty Pasetta, George Stevens Jr and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This series from the American Film Institute (AFI) salutes some of the biggest stars that shaped the face of Hollywood. Jimmy (James) Stewart whose career spanned over 45 years having acted in over 80 films is honoured here with an AFI Lifetime Achievement Award. Jimmy became an American icon and came to symbolise the greatest of American family values. Especially noted in this program is Jimmy’s unique ability of bringing his characters to life. As an audience we lose the sense of the actor acting and are transported by the real feeling given to his characters. Excerpts from some of his best known films are shown ‘It’s a wonderful life’, ‘Rear window’, ‘Mr Smith goes to Washington’, ‘Harvey’ and much more. Princess Grace of Monaco (Grace Kelly) gives a rare Hollywood appearance amongst others of his colleagues including: Walter Matthau, Jack Lemmon, Charlton Heston, Spencer Tracy, Henry Fonda, Gene Kelly, Dustin Hoffman and Alfred Hitchcock.

results.title: The American Film Institute salute to Gene Kelly
results.creator_credit: Don Mischer, George Stevens and American Film Institute
results.brief_description: This series from the American Film Institute (AFI) salutes some of the biggest stars that shaped the face of Hollywood. The charming and enchanting Gene Kelly is honoured in this tribute hosted by Shirley Maclaine. Through many film excerpts of his cinematic career, including For Me and My Gal (1942), An American in Paris (1951), Take Me Out to the Ballgame (1949), Cover Girl (1944), Singin’ in the Rain (1952) we see the wonderful genius and style of this multi-talented dancer, director, actor, and choreographer. Take a walk down memory lane as a number of Hollywood stars including Fred Astaire, James Stewart, Debbie Reynolds, Donald O’Connor, Cyd Charisse, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Leslie Caron and Olivia Newton-John celebrate Gene Kelly’s accomplishments with their own personal stories and reminiscings.

results.title: The Ambassador
results.brief_description:
‘The Ambassador’, is a short film featuring veteran actor, Wynn Roberts (from Picnic At Hanging Rock) as a man who writes to the Minister for the Environment to advocate for the forests and the animals that live in them.

The film is built around real events: Wynn has lived much of his 95 years in the forest. It also references climate change, ongoing logging, the staggering loss of wildlife during the recent mega fires and showcases wildlife from the southeast forests. The film won the 2020 BVSC Best Environment Film Award.

Details on Wynn Roberts can be found here - https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0731687/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1

results.title: The Amazing adventure
results.brief_description: Cary Grant returned to England to make “The Amazing adventure” one of the few films he made outside of Hollywood in the 1930s. Grant plays Ernest Bliss, a man who is independently wealthy due to an inheritance but whose life lacks meaning. Suffering a type of depression exclusive to the idle rich, Bliss consults a doctor who wages Bliss 50,000 pounds that he can’t last a year earning his own keep. Bliss determines to meet the challenge and sets off in search of employment. Depression era London proves to be a tough life for Bliss, whose experiences over the year shape him significantly. The bet is set awry when Bliss meets Frances - a woman being forced to marry for money despite her reciprocated love for Bliss. The film adheres to the Depression formula of a man who renounces his wealth in order to experience life first hand and learn lessons of good-hearted common people. This version is the 62-minute American release. Also starring Mary Brian, Peter Gawthorne, and Henry Kendall. Based on the book by English novelist E. Phillips Oppenheimer.

results.title: The Allan Border tribute match
results.brief_description: In front of a capacity crowd and television audiences Australia-wide, Allan Border’s XI crept home to a last ball win over the International XI. A selection of cricketing legends and sporting personalities were brought together to pay tribute to the man who was one of Australian cricket’s greatest captains and all-round star. Due to the nature of the original footage from the National Nine Network telecast of 19 December 1993, some minor technical faults may appear.

results.title: The Age of 14 or 15 = Shi si wu sui
results.creator_credit: Lin A'mian, Zhao Yuan and Beijing Children's Film Company
results.brief_description:
Over the past hundred years, the age of 14 has become an extremely influential period in the average educated Chinese person’s life. In Europe, the US or Australia, a whole genre of films have sought to capture this right of passage in a young person’s life, where they explore their changing bodies, their own sense of identity and the world of ideas and morality. But these experiences don’t even count for small change in China.

A boarding school filled with young adults might invite these connotations in Western countries, however we are shown this period is influential for completely different reasons in the PRC. The beginning of junior high means the pressure is really on: From this moment on, the young teens face extreme competition with one another in order to excel in their studies and make the grade for the best possible high-school, which is the only way of standing a chance at university admission.

It is therefore a period of both extreme tension and vigorous excitement. No longer treated as children, these young adults feel that they have been invested with the responsibility for their own fate. However, the film also highlights the commonplace attitude — especially among children from rural areas — where they vow to commit suicide if they do not achieve the necessary grade for the best high school.

With this said, we might expect the schools to be churning out utter monsters. Quite the opposite, in fact. Indeed, the extreme pressure and excitement of this time inspires a deep sense of cameraderie between them, as they recognise that they are not alone in their struggle. Of course, competition always manages to bring out the worst antisocial traits in a select few, but the group overall are seen to flourish, often going to great pains to stick their neck out for each other.

The film explains the powerful bond made between friends and classmates of these years, and how struggle is not only a necessary part of life, but teaches us how to empathise with others and work together. The contemporary view of this film is more likely to equate to something like: Harry Potter, with no magic, in Communist China.

Among the film’s many themes it examines antisocial personality traits, with plenty of cheating in basketball games, skirting labor, cherrypicking others’ praise, taking advantage of the latitudes of the system, etc. However, we are expected to understand that, in all these situations, it is the Truth which shines through in the long run to reveal people’s true intentions and motives.

Although the children are shown to celebrate their 14th year, it would be more realistic to see this as an expression of general nostalgia for those who have left those more simple times behind. The film, therefore, advocates that this is the time young people should appreciate fully the joy of being alive before moving on to a glorious future (something that any young person can expect to be told by their elders).
(3 stars - James Donald; June 10, 2011)
